advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the time of this advert (September 1980), Heathkit introduced a music synthetiser board, a speech lab, a color graphic board, a color monitor and Microsoft BASIC and FORTRAN languages. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHRISTMAS 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"><b> A smart investment</b><br> Radio Shack's popular TRS-80 Color Computer is now on sale. You can get this complete, versatile system with a 16 K-byte memory and Standard Color BASIC language for only $299.95 (Cat. No. 26-3004, reg. $399.95). It's the affordable way for the entire family to start computing.</font><br><br> The Extended BASIC - 16 KB version was priced $399.95<br> The 32 KB version was priced $549.95.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR 'MOBILE' COURSE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME WITH A MAN</strong></font><br><blockquote>Less impressive...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING FOR THE BM JR</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In March 1983, the price of the assembled version decreased of $20 ($79.95 instead of $99.95)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £149 IN JUNE 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Yeno DPC 64 leaves major of MSX"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: GTE (Geometry Transformation Engine), Data Decompression Engine (MDEC), GPU, SPU
computer.description:
After Sony and Nintendo's collaboration on the Super CD-ROM came to an end, Sony continued their research and decided to make a stand alone console. A deal was reached with Nintendo to allow the Play Station (as it was called then) to play SNES cartridges. This feature was dropped from the final design, and the name changed to PlayStation.
A powerful machine, the PlayStation featured 3D graphics capabilities which at the time were remarkable. Games like Tomb Raider made 3D game worlds popular and effectively put an end to the 2D shoot 'em ups and platformers which had been around since the late '70s and early '80s.
Early units suffered from problems with the laser mechanism. The CD tray was made from plastic and over a period of time would wear away resulting in games no longer working. A common solution was to turn the console on its side or even upside down to relieve stress on the laser's motor. Later units had a metal tray to prevent this problem.
Even to this day the PlayStation is often wrongly referred to as the PSX, the correct term being PS. PSX was the name given to the PlayStation based arcade hardware and later a Japanese only version of the PS2, which was capable of digital video recording and featured either a 160 GB or 250 GB hard drive.
A redesigned machine named PSone was released in 2000. This smaller version lacked the serial port but was otherwise fully compatible with older games. The PS and PSone achieved combined sales of more than 102 million units between them, making the PlayStation the first ever console to break the 100 million mark. In the process PlayStation became a household name, ended Nintendo's domination of the market and fought off competition from Sega's Saturn and Dreamcast, which no doubt had an influence on Sega's decision to pull out of the console hardware business.
______________
Contributors: Ste (text & info)

computer.keyboard: Original - 8-way d-pad, 8 buttons + Start + SelectDual Analog - 8-way d-pad, 10 buttons + Start + Select, two analogue sticksDualShock had the same layout but was able to vibrate
computer.name: PlayStation
computer.ports: Expansion port, Serial port, AV out, 2 Memory Card slots, 2 controller ports
